L. B. 389 same session allocated the following specific amounts to the program: 1. The State Assistance Program has been operating during the year - ending June 30, 1939, under the State Plan approved by the Social Security j Board under date of August 17, 1937. (See pages Ito 5, in - clusive, Second Annual Report Department of State Assistance and Child Welfare, year ending June 30, 1938.) The' Fifty-third Legislative Session commenced on January 3, 1939 and enacted many--laws affecting the State' Assistance Program. Follow - ing is a memorandum sent to all county assistance offices, under date of i June 1939, in reference to the newly-enacted legislation bearing upon State Assistance:

EXHIBIT A RESUME OF 1939 SESSION LAWS RELATING TO THE STATE ASSISTANCE PROGRAM Lincoln, Nebraska June 20, 1939 L. B. 13. Specifically reappropriated the funds held by the State Treasurer in the State Assistance Fund during the 1937-39 biennium which were received from the State Gasoline Highway Fund but, owing to a discrepancy in the last biennium appropriation bill, were not avail - able to apply on the 17,500,000.00 appropriation until this L. B. 13 was passed. L. B. 15. Provides for a maximum of one mill levy by counties during the year 1939 and 1940 upon taxable property for the relief of the unemployed and indigent persons and further provides that of this one mill levy not to exceed 5% in counties having population not to exceed 150,000 and not to exceed 10% in counties having population jof more than 150,000, shall be expended for salaries and expenses of ad - ministration of such activities. This law may make it necessary for County Boards to give serious i-onsideration as to the need for providing for adequate funds to carry on necessary administration of their relief programs. We suggest that attention be called to all County Boards by all County Assistance Directors to this matter. L. B. 235. Provides for one cent gas tax to inure to State Assist - ance Fund during biennium beginning July 1, 1939. Last biennium one - half cent from this Fund inured to State Assistance. L. B. 270. Provides that only such persons as meet the Social Security standards may receive Aid to Dependent Children grants, the old statute covering this matter permitted persons to be eligible to receive these giants who were not listed in the Social Security Act and the state could not receive federal matching on those cases. L. B. 338. Provides specifically that the State Board of Control has authority to establish a personnel plan and to establish reasonable rules find regulations governing the administration of said plan, as well as all phases of the administration of the State Assistance program, and yaid leasonable rules and regulations shall be binding upon the counties of the State of Nebraska. This bill also provides that 4% of State Assistance Funds may be used by counties, having less than 200,000 population, for administrative purposes and 5% in counties having in excess of 200,000 population for administrative purposes. L. B. 351. Provides that Blind Assistance shall be on the Need 2

Basisand also provides that the minimum grant shall be $5.0.0. The old statutes placed the minimum grant at $15.00. Persons receiving Blind Assistance may also receive vocational rehabilitation. L. B. 389. Provides that Old Age.Assistance shall be on the need basis land indicates how need will be determined. Provides that not more jthan % of State Assistance Fund may be expended' in any one eighth of said biennium, unless accumulated balances from prior Is periods were available, in which case said balances may be used. Provides for the lien on real estate belonging to old age assistance recipients, or in; which they have an interest. Intended to provide that no burials covering old age, blind, or aid to dependent children should be paid from State Assistance Funds. : Permits county supplementation of old age assistance grants under certain conditions. : : ' V :.'¦. L. B. 390. Provides additional one per cent fund for use in assist - ance or certification administration expenses in counties, provides break - down of funds f0r,1939-41 biennium; $178,000.00 Child Welfare, Crippled Children; and Boarding Home Care, 8% balance for certification and surplus commodity distribution, balance for payment Blind Assistance grants ift full and balance for Old Age and Aid to Dependent Children grants. ; This bill aiso provides the need for assistance shall be based upon the budgetary deficiency and indicates the items to be considered as necessary for the recipient's maintenance in decency and health, taking into consideration his requirements for rent, food, clothing, shelter, fuel, light, -water, household equipment and supplies, health, education, and such other factors as may be pertinent. L. B. 429. Provides that State Assistance Funds be allocated to counties for balance of 1937-39 biennium on need basis. L. B. 492. Provides that State Liquor Tax inure to State Assistance prograniifor biennium beginning 1 July 1,1939. i -.'. ' L. B. 493. Provides for reallocation of all accumulated balances in counties. This bill was necessary at the time that the allocation of funds was placed on the need basis. : ¦ i .¦•..¦ ¦"¦¦• :i „: ¦ ¦ .-¦ ¦ ¦I .': ¦.-.¦.' ¦;¦. L. B. 494. Provides an additional $300,000.00, making the total available for State Assistance program for 1937-39 biennium $7,800,000.00. :.'¦;¦.¦ ";C : L. B. 519. Provides sum of $400,000.00 by way of a revolving fund to supplement State Assistance Fund to effect the more punctual admin - istration of the Assistance laws of the state. L. B. 521. Is the State Budget Bill for biennium beginning July 1, 1939 and provides ?8,400,000.00 for the State Assistance program. 3

Many other bills pertaining to the State Assistance program were proposed. The above 14 bills provided for most of the recommendations made by the Governor in his message to the Legislature under date of .January 5, 1939 which reads as follows in respect to the Social Security program handled by State Assistance. EXCERPT FROM GOVERNOR COCHRAN'S MESSAGE DELIVERED TO THE FIFTY-THIRD SESSION OF THE LEGISLATURE OF NEBRASKA January 5, 1939 Mr. Chairman and Members of the Nebraska Legislature: SOCIAL SECURITY Three years ago, Nebraska adopted a social security program pro - viding for old age assistance, aid to crippled and dependent children, and to the blind. The first appropriation was for $3,036,054.13 per year. The second appropriation was for $3,750,000.00 per year. The total number on June Ist, 1936, receiving old age assistance was 20,600. The total number on June Ist, 1937, was 26,839. The total number as of .June Ist, 1938, was 26,357. The total number today is 26,808. At the time this honorable body was in session two years ago, when appropriations were made for this governmental service, the number on old age assistance was constantly increasing and it was recognized liy the legislature that a closer supervision was needed to the end that the ineligibles be eliminated and that those most deserving of assistance would receive more equitable benefits. As a result, the legislature directed the transfer of the administration of old age assistance and related activities to the State Board of Control with provision for the appointment of a Director of Assistance by the Governor to be confirmed Ijy the legislature. Within a very short time after the new administration of social security became effective, reductions were effected in the old age assistance rolls. Had not this closer supervision been effected, it is my opinion that more than 30,000 would be receiving old age assistance at the present time instead of 26,808. I say this because during that period, 4,808 new cases have been added to the rolls and 4,839 have been subtracted from the rolls. To a small extent the elimination of those on the rolls was due to removal from the state and some reductions were effected through death. However, large reductions were accomplished through closer scrutiny resulting in discovery and elimination of inelig - ible cases. 4

While there have been recent increases in the rolls at the rate of about 150 per month, it is felt from the experience thus far had that the upward trend can be broken and perhaps actual reductions accom - plished by an extension of trained personnel selected on the basis of a merit system by which only persons of demonstrated ability and knowl - edge of the program may be employed on this program. Legislation should be passed which will provide the necessary authority for the State Assistance Director to install a merit system in the Assistance Program covering both state and county personnel, re - taining, however, the maximum of local control possible. I wish to advise you thatisuch legislation will be necessary in order to insure a continua - tion of federal participation. / : As you know, the allocation of funds for social security is now made among the various counties of the state on the basis of population. During the past two years, we have had difficulty in securing approval of this plan by the Federal Social Security Board. We have been unable to secure' approval of our plan, but we have been able to receive federal funds on the promise that I recommend to this legislature that our law be corrected so as to provide that all allocations to counties be made on the basis of need instead of on the basis of population. In passing such legislation, it is recommended that a provision be inserted stating that the [ Director of Assistance may use the assistance needs as shown by the records on June Ist, 1938, to determine the allotments to be made to the various counties. .-¦; I . House Roll No. 17 of the Special Session of 1935, which provides for old age assistance payments of $30 per month less income, should be amended to conform with the federal law and the determination of payments on a need basis. We see a growing tendency by which persons plan ahead for the time when they will be 65 years of age, when they feel there will be a grant for them. Some dispose of their property. In some cases, relatives who have supported indigent old people up to the time they are sixty - five years of age, refuse to do so any longer. In short, we see a tendency for the people to plan for! an impoverished old age so that they can receive public assistance. We see a constantly reduced feeling of re - sponsibility upon the part of relatives. We see an absence of thrift and an increased tendency to disregard moral and legal responsibilities toward relatives in distress. . .•¦.-•¦.¦ The administration; of assistance can be'helped immeasurably by a proper interest on the part of our citizens generally, as well as by those in public office, by calling attention to any cases where family responsi - bility is being neglected or the law evaded. The carrying out of such a program will redound to greater benefits for those in actual need with - out other means of support; family or otherwise. I recommend the pas - sage, by your honorable body, of legislation which will make the laws 5

with reference to family responsibility more effective. Many of the troubles that I have described arise from a quite general misconception of our present program. What we have today is an assistance or relief program based on need, not a pension program based on inherent right. It is felt that if first liens could be placed against property belong - ing to old age assistance recipients, considerable refunds would be col - lected and it might possibly keep some ineligible persons from applying for assistance. Attention is called to the legislative error made at the close of the 1937 session by which one-tenth of one cent of gasoline tax, intended for social security, was in fact not appropriated for any purpose. It cannot be expended for any purpose until it has been appropriated by the legislature. It is recommended that an emergency appropriation be made by your honorable body at as early a date as possible correcting the legislative error made in 1937 and making available the proceeds from the one-tenth of one cent of gasoline tax to which I have just referred. I emphasize this matter for the reason that this appropriation will be necessary in order to make payments to the counties on January 15th. This does not contemplate any increase over the seven and one - half million dollars appropriated by the legislature of 1937 for social security, but would make available the seven and one-half million dollars as the legislature and the governor intended. Reallocation of accumulated totals in counties where the needs are less than the present allotments also will be necessary. This will likewise require emergency legislation. It is recommended that revenue be appropriated in order to main - tain at least the present standards of old age assistance, aid to depen - dent and crippled children, and to the blind. As a suggestion and rec - ommendation the following estimates may serve as a guide as to amounts and sources of revenue: Beer and liquor taxes $1,500,000.00 Per Head Tax 1,000,000.00 Gas Tax from % of lc 1,650,000.00 Estate Tax 50,000.00 Total $4,200,000.00 In addition to the above, it is estimated that $125,000 per year additional may be obtained in federal funds for aid to dependent children and the blind by matching same with county funds raised by levies for mother's pensions and for the blind. The present state appropriation per year for these activities is $3,750,000.00. It is recognized that the above sources and estimated amounts yield an amount somewhat in excess of the present three and three-quarter millions of dollars expended annually. However, it is pos - sible, if not probable, that the per head tax collections may be less than 6

the estimated amount shown, but it is believed that legislation can be passed to make the per bead tax collections more effective. Respectfully submitted, , V E. L.COCHRAN, ¦'¦¦¦¦»..';;.. Governor. With further reference to statement in Governor Cochran's message cited above in which he suggested the possibility of securing $125,000.00 per year additional from Federal matching of Mother's Pension funds and Blind Levy funds provided these levies met certain Federal quali - fications! attention is called to the fact that recent Federal legislation providesj for Federal matching on the basis of dollar for dollar after Jan. 1, 1940 instead of fifty cents Federal for each dollar of State funds, therefore the amount available through Federal matching would be pro - portionally increased after Jan; 1, 1940 over what was available at the time this message was written. Additional Federal legislation provides for Federal matching of administrative costs of Aid to Dependent Children and Blind Assistance after Jan. 1,1940 to be on a dollar for dollar cost matching basis. This will make it necessary for the state to certify to the Social Security Board as to the administrative costs of each of these operations in order to have a sound: basis for receiving the Federal proportional matching, and in order to make this certification to the Social Security Board the State Assistance is carrying on a time study throughout the state in order to determine administrative costs of each County Assistance and State Assistance office. The State Assistance grants in.the various categories have varied in amount considerably from county to county during the time that the funds were allocated to counties on the basis of population. L. B. 429 was enacted by the Fifty-third Legislature on March 17, 1939. Since March 17, 1939 the State Assistance funds have been allocated to the various counties on the basis of need as determined by the various county assistance committees and approved by the State Assistance office. In order to effect an equitable basis to calculate the individual needs of persons receiving State Assistance grants the State Office has sup - plied all counties with instructions (See State Manual) governing the various procedures including a Standard State Budget which furnishes detailed information relative to individual "needs" and how to determine them.;i. „ ¦:;.'; -"... '.f.': ¦ '¦,;¦¦'•:. Since the State Assistance receives a fixed appropriation and since this appropriation in the 1937-39 biennium was inadequate to pay the 7

"needs" of the grantees in full it was necessary to make pro rate deduc - tions in the grants in proportion to the funds available. The average need per old age recipient as calculated in November, 1938 for the six-months' period just preceding- was $18.50 per grantee! The average "need" per blind case was calculated as $22.50 and the average "need" per A.D.C. family was calculated at $28.28. By using the above figures and assuming some figures regarding the probable number of persons who would receive Old Age, Blind and A.D.C. grants it is possible to calculate the amount of funds required for airy given program. The State Assistance edits a monthly report giving various statistical data in reference to the State Assistance program. These reports are available to interested persons upon request. The State Assistance program has acquired increased responsibilities because of various factors chief of which has been the assumption Jan. 1, 1938 of the N.E.R.A. activities. Also, the continued drouth over the state which has resulted in increasing the load upon practically all relief agencies and reduction of administrative and relief funds in many coun - ties has made the situation even more acute, and the increased number of persons on the Assistance rolls has resulted in decreased average grants to recipients. The difficult economic conditions over the state have resulted in many families who are not receiving relief grants being reduced to relief stand - ards of living and many others being unable to continue to assist in the support of dependent relatives resulting in additional numbers of persons being added to the State Assistance rolls and as the number of recipients increases the average payments to Old Age and A.D.C. became less and less. 8

PERSONNEL Those persons-conscious of the piesent day needs of public service in America emphasize in their thinking the importance of qualified per - sonnel to cope with the intricate problems of administration. Since the amount of money expended monthly by the county assistance agency for the various types of aid makes the agency one of the largest businesses in any county, it is highly important to secure for public service men and women of capacity commensurate with the varied and complex re - sponsibilities. The public assistance agency has long ceased to be a second-rate business. It requires qualified men and women who are con - stantly seeking ways to increase the effectiveness of their work. The attitude,'of the public assistance worker is basic; eve*ry worker needs these important qualities, among others, to succeed: ] 1. A belief in people as individuals; 2. Patience and sympathy with the shortcomings of human nature; 3. A conviction that scrupulously fair, honest, and direct dealing with individuals is the one best method which will best serve them; ¦¦:•¦' 4. An open-minded and an unemotional approach to the individual problem.* The Department of State Assistance and Child Welfare is making every attempt to reach out into the proper channels in order to attract worth-while people. It maintains an active, year-around recruitment pro - gram as a part of the merit system. It solicits the help of County Assist - ance Committees, County Assistance Directors, and taxpayers who are willing to recommend the better qualified men and women possessing vision, ambition, integrity) and a good personality in addition to other attributes, some of which have been mentioned. Definite progress has been made toward the selection of personnel on a merit basis and toward the application of principles of personnel administration involved in a merit system since the submission of the State plan in 1937. The most important steps in the application of the merit system were the appointment of an Examining Board and the issuance of regulations for the merit system in July, 1938. Upon the adoption of these regulations, a voluntary merit system was put into operation. This plan is still in effect. Statement of Policy The State policy contained in the regulations is indicative of the desires of the Board of Control to establish a thoroughgoing system. The statement of policy is as follows: Rule I contains the statement of policy. - : i ¦ i¦ ; ;¦¦.- . ,' .¦¦" . '.: •. Tenner, Jessamine C, Personnel Manual; The Personnel Function in Non-technical Language, rev. cd.!, 1936. 9

'In order to assure an efficient and economical administration of the functions of the State and county assistance programs and to provide equal opportunity for all qualified persona to compete for positions in State and county assistance departments, the Board of Control has adopted definite regulations to carry out the merit principle. All appoint - ments shall be made on a nonpartisan basis. Positions shall be filled from registers of eligibles estabished by examinations except for appointments to clerical, stenographic, and secretarial positions, and provisional appointments. "... the Board of Control will make possible a career service in the State Department by making promotions based on efficient work and providing tenure in office for those who give satisfactory performance and to encourage' such a policy in county assistance administrations. "No appointment to or removal from a position in the classified service shall be effected or influenced in any manner by any political social or religious affiliations." In Rule II is found the definition of the classified service. "The term classified service means all officers or positions in the State and County Assistance programs, except the following: (a) mem - bers of the Board of Control; (b) the Director; (c) the members of County Assistance Committees; (d) members of the Examining Board." Voluntary Merit System The registers which were established as a result of the voluntary merit system became effective in January, 1939. The examinations were given in August, 1938, and registers were established for the following positions: County Offices Junior Visitor Senior Supervisor Senior Visitor Case Work Supervisor Case Worker County Assistance Director State Office Field Representative Junior Accounting Clerk Field Reviewer Statistician Certification Reviewer Senior Statistical Clerk Field Auditor Junior Statistical Clerk Senior Accounting Clerk Supervisor, Division of Research and Statistics No examinations were given for any clerical, stenographic, or secre - tarial position. 10

Legal Authority—L. B. 338 The Legislature of 1939 passed a law authorizing the Board of Control to establish a personnel plan and adopt regulations governing the same. The law became effective upon its approval by the Governor on April 22,1939. The law as enacted by the Legislature is as follows: ¦¦'' ¦ ¦ ¦ ¦ (Legislative Bill 338) "Be it Enacted by the People of the State of Nebraska 1 "Section 1. That Sec. 68-326, Comp. St. Supp., 19^7, be amended to read las follows: . . ; "68-326. The Board of Control of state institutions shall have authority to establish a personnel plan and to establish reasonable rules and regulations governing the administration of said plan as well as all phases of the administration of the state assistance program, and said reasonable rules and regulations shall be binding upon the counties of the state of Nebraska. The board of county commissioners or super - visors, as the case may be, and the county board of public welfare, if now or j hereafter lawfully in existence in each respective county of the state of Nebraska, are hereby, designated as the County Assistance Com - mittee of each respective county. The County Assistance Committee shall have the powers and duties now or hereafter vested in it by law. It may employ such clerks and assistants as may be necessary to enable it properly to administer its duties, and shall pay such personnel rea - sonable salaries arid wages and necessary expenses; Provided, that county employees necessary for the administration of the assistance program shall be selected by the County Assistance Committee in accordance with standards set up for the state by the Board of Control of state institutions; provided, however, that no more than four per cent of the 'money allocated for assistance to any county under this Act, plus any available county funds for such purposes, shall be expended for salaries and expenses of administration of such activities in such county;' and provided further, that in any county having a population of two | hundred thousand inhabitants or more, no more than five per cent of the money allocated for assistance to such county under this Act, plus any available county funds for such purposes, shall be expended for salaries and expenses of administration/"6i such activities in such county. . ; '";¦ "Sec. 2; That said original Sec. 68-326, Comp. St. Supp., 1937, is hereby repealed. . "Sec. 3. Whereas, anemergency exists, this Act shall be in full force and talie effect, from and after its passage and approval, according to law. [;¦'; ' '.-.- .¦¦¦¦; . ;. . ¦ ¦ ¦ ¦ ... "Approved, April 22, i 939." 11

SYSTEM OF ADMINISTRATION Organization A division of personnel was established on January 1, 1938, and is headed by a Supervisor. The Personnel Division is one of six divisions in the Department of State Assistance and Child Welfare, the others being the Divisions of Child Welfare, Research and Statistics, Public Assistance, Commodity Distribution, and Accounting and Finance. The section of the regulations (Rule 111, Section 2) which describes the duties of the Supervisor of the Division of Personnel is as follows: "A Division of Personnel shall be established and shall be headed by a Supervisor. Under the direction of the Director and in accordance with the rules and regulations adopted by the Board of Control, the Supervisor of Personnel shall supervise all activities of the Personnel Division; and it shall be his duty to supervise and make effective the provisions of these rules and regulations, including the preparation and administration of a classification plan; a compensation plan, transfer, promotion, lay-off, and dismissal of employees (State Department and assistance to County Assistance Committees as requested); evaluation of employees' services; maintenance of a service roster card for each employee, and other records and files; certification of individual pay vouchers or employee pay rolls; recommendations for changes and im - provements in these rules and regulations; preparation of monthly and annual reports of the operations of the Personnel Division and of the distribution, turn-over, and other matters relating to employment; and to do all things lawful which he deems necessary or desirable to secure the successful operation of the personnel plan in accordance with the provisions of these rules and regulations." / Examining Board The Board of Control has the assistance of an advisory committee on personnel known as the Examining Board. The organization and the duties of the Examining Board are set forth in the regulations as follows: (Rule 11. Definition of Terms) "... The term Examining Board means the Board for adminis - tration of examinations." Rule 111. Section I. "The Board of Control shall appoint a committee which shall be known as the Examining Board. The Examining Board shall be com - posed of three members who shall be known to have a knowledge of public welfare administration, and to be interested in the improvement of public administration and in the selection of efficient personnel. They 12

shall be public-spirited citizens with recognized standing in their respec - tive fields and shall possess reputations for impartiality. The Examining Board shall form its own organization and designate a chairman, vice - chairman, and a recording secretary whose duty it shall be to keep a complete record of the transactions of all meetings. The Supervisor of Personnel shall attend all meetings of the Examining Board and partici - pate in| the discussion but shall have no vote. Members of the Examin - ing Board shall serve from the time of their appointment until June 30, 1939, or until their successors are appointed. The Examining Board shall be responsible for all preparations for holding and grading exami - nations, including the determination of number of examination centers; arrangements for space; securing and instruction of proctors and oral interviewing committees; for the approval of test questions; for holding and grading all parts of the examination; and for establishing and main - taining of eligible lists and for certifications from such lists. It shall, also, be the duty of the Examining Board to promote public understand - ing of; the purposes, policies, and practices of the merit system. The Examining Board shall make a written report to the Board of Control on theioperation of the merit system on or before the first of October of each year. Such report shall be filed with the Board of Control and he open to public inspection. Meetings of the Examining Board shall be held as often as are practical and necessary at the call of the chairman or by the Board of Control. : . "Members of the Examining Board shall receive no salary but may be compensated for ordinary expenses incurred, including travel and maintenance while engaged in the performance of their duties." The Examining Board was appointed by the Board of Control in June, 1938. It consists of the following persons: Dr. Hattie Plum Wil - liams, (Mr. Thomas J. Dredla, and Judge Fred A. Wright. Dr. Hattie Plum Williams is Professor of Sociology at the Uni - versity of Nebraska and is the undergraduate advisor for social work students. She has been interested in the administration of public wel - fare in Nebraska for many years and is one of the State's outstanding authorities on welfare legislation. She received the first award for dis - tinctive service ever granted by the Nebraska Conference for Social Work. The only similar awards were given to the Misses Grace and Edith j Abbott of Chicago. Dr. Williams is very competent to perform the service as a member of the Examining Board and has entered enthusi - astically into the work, . The second member of the Board is Mr. Thomas J. Dredla who is a prominent attorney in Crete, Nebraska. Mr. Dredla has traveled ex - tensively, visiting Europe four times. On these trips he studied social security as it operates in England and as it operated in Czechoslovakia. 13

.Mr. Dredla was formerly County Attorney of Saline County and has a very extensive legal practice. He was recommended as a member of the Examining Board by the Nebraska Association of County Commissioners, Supervisors, Highway Commissioners, County Clerks, and Registers of Heeds. Judge Fred A. Wright is the third member of the Board and is also a prominent attorney. He is practicing in Omaha, Nebraska. Mr. Wright was formerly District Judge in the Fourth Judicial District and was also a member of the Omaha School Board for several years. He is inter - ested in all matters pertaining to public welfare and has a wide acquaint - ance throughout the State of Nebraska. After the Board of Control and the Examining Board had approved the rules and regulations but before approving or publishing the quali - fications for any position, a classification plan was written. It was necessary to analyze the educational and employment his - tories of the present County Assistance Directors. The following informa - tion was compiled as the result: (1) 48% or approximately one-half the county assistance directors in the State were over 40 years of age; (2) 69% were natives of the State of Nebraska r (3) 47% had no university or college training; (4) 23% were ex-teachers; (5) 10% were ex-bank cashiers; and (6) 8% were ex-bookkeepers. With these statistics in mind, a study was made to find out how many college graduates resided in each county. A study of the Uni - versity of Nebraska alumni records was made. It was found there were a large number of university graduates in practically every county. The number of graduates who were employed and unemployed could not be ascertained. After several long discussions with members of the Examining Board, the representatives of the Social Security Board, and the Committee of county commissioners, it was felt that a basic educational requirement of two years of college work for the positions of Junior and Senior Visitor, Senior Supervisor, and County Assistance Director, with substitutions, would immediately raise Nebraska personnel standards and that it was a goal which could be attained. A goal which would give the Depart - ment a sufficient number of names on the registers from which all vacancies could be filled during the next year. In most of the counties in the State, there are unified programs, one office with one director handling certifications and administering cate - gorical assistance. Most of the counties are proud of these unified pro - grams. In establishing the first merit system, it was desirable to "blanket in" persons already employed in assistance offices and performing satis - factory work. They were permitted to take the examinations for the positions they held regardless of whether or not they possessed the mini - mum educational qualifications. The voluntary merit system has proved to be inclusive of the representative forces within the state assistance 14

program and is also flexible and adaptable to the widely varying needs arid situations. ' .', ¦ . . A merit system consists of the following parts: (1) the grading of experience and education; (2) the assembled examination or the un - assembled examination; and (3) the oral examination; or (4) any com - bination. A probationary period, of course, is an intrinsic part. i The Department of State Assistance and Child Welfare made sev - eral public announcements of the examinations. A broad and active policy of recruitment was adopted, and publicity was looked to as one positive means of influencing desirable types of applicants. Three weeks were allowed between the first newspaper announcement and the closing date for the receipt of applications, which date was July 30, 1938. The public announcement program included a large poster contain - ing the essential information. This poster was placed in almost all the post offices, libraries, county assistance offices, and courthouses through - out the State. The merit system was discussed at public meetings. Any person who had ever applied to the Department of State Assistance and Child Welfare was sent an application blank, poster, copy of state assistance laws, and a twenty-eight page pamphlet defining each position in detail, the minimum educational requirements, and the personal quali - fications. The pamphlet also informed applicants as to the method of filing applications, closing date, time and place of written examinations, as well as residence, age, and health requirements. Five thousand of these pamphlets were distributed in Nebraska and have been read by a large number of persons, giving them a much better idea of the public assistance worker's duties. A liberal supply of posters and pamphlets were mailed to state, county, and city officials; federal offices in the State; schools, colleges, and universities; professional societies and clubs; libraries; newspapers; industrial firms; employment offices; labor, fraternal, civic, veterans', and political organizations. The response was gratifying, as 1,814 applications were, submitted, representing 1,600 persons. The written examinations for all the accounting and statistical posi - tions were prepared in collaboration with the Social Security Board. The examinations for the Division of Public Assistance were prepared by a committee of Field Representatives after an exhaustive study of exami - nations used in other states, innumerable conferences with recognized leaders in the field of public welfare, and much research and reading on the part of certain representatives. The questions were submitted to and reviewed by a representative of the Social Security Board. The examinations were of the short-answer, objective type and' were tested as much as possible as to reliability in accordance with certain factors which influence test reliability. The written examinations were given August 29 and 30, 1938, and the oral examinations were conducted during the months of November and December, 1938. - ' ¦. 15

In all examinations, the minimum rating or standing through which eligibility on a register could be earned was seventy per cent. An appli - cant's grade was based upon a weighted sum of the various factors of the total examination. Failure in any part of the examination disqualified the applicant in the entire examination. All applicants for the same position were accorded uniform and equal treatment in all phases of the examination procedure. For the oral examinations, the Examining Board appointed one Oral Examining Committee consisting of four members who were interested in the improvement of public administration and the selection of efficient personnel. The Oral Examining Committee was composed of Mr. W. H. Andresen, Mr. L. E. Moore, Dr. E. Glenn Callen, and a Field Representa - tive from the Department of State Assistance and Child Welfare. Dr. Roy J. W. Ely assisted the Oral Examining Committee with the examin - ing of applicants for Field Auditor. Each candidate was notified by mail of his rating as soon as the scoring of examinations had been completed and the registers estab - lished. The date of this notification was January 1, 1939. The Examining Board used the services of a large number of public - spirited individuals and organizations and wishes to acknowledge its indebtedness to them, as they served without remuneration and often at a personal sacrifice. The Board is indebted to the County Superin - tendents of Schools and their assistants who served as Proctors for the written examinations; to the school boards for the use of city high school buildings where the written examinations were given; to the members of the Oral Examining Committee; and to the Committee of County Commissioners. Hotels Norfolk at Norfolk, Lincoln at Scottsbluff, Key - stone at McCook, Pawnee at North Platte, Yancey at Grand Island, and Kontenelle at Omaha donated rooms in which to hold the oral examina - tions. Numerous persons have worked long hours in order to help per - fect the examinations. The Examining Board is indebted to them and to everyone who helped to make the merit system workable. DIVISION OF ASSISTANCE The Division of Assistance of the Department of Assistance and Child Welfare has responsibility for seeing that the social security grant-in-aid programs in Nebraska are, administered effectively, that certification to federal agencies,—Works 1 Progress Administration, Na - tional Youth Administration, Civilian Conservation Corps, Farm Security Administration, is made in compliance with regulations and on the basis of need, | and that surplus commodities are allotted to persons who meet eligibility requirements. These programs have been established by the federal government in cooperation with state and local units on the basis that the government owes its citizen assurance of security for him - self and^ his family—an opportunity, if he is able, to participate in the economy! of the country by work; if he is unable to work, and meets certain qualifications, to provide for his basic needs through regular monthly grants in cash. The work programs make possible work for wages, whereby the employed person is enabled to participate and make his contribution to the community, receiving wages rather than a dole. The Social Security Act attempts to provide safeguards against some of the chief misfor - tunes of. life that lead to dependency and poverty. Greater security and •welfare are;afforded children through several programs, the grant-in-aid .program for dependent children being the responsibility of the Division 'of Assistance of the State Department. Old Age security is provided by ' two very different methods, one of which —assistance grants for aged persons in need—is the responsibility of the Division. Aid to the needy blind is included as a grant-in-aid program, and the Division of Assist - | ance is charged with the efficient operation of these activities. I The Board of Control, through the Department of Assistance and Child Welfare, is charged by law for the responsibility of the grant-ma - id programs of the Social Security Act, namely Old Age Assistance, I Blind Assistance, and Aid to Dependent Children. To the Division of i Assistance of the Department is assigned the task of establishing policies | and procedures for the operation of the Nebraska program, and of super - visingl the programs in the ninety-three counties of the state. In general, ! unemployed; persons fulfilling certain technical requirements, including age and; residence, and who are without sufficient resources, are eligible. • Specifically, to be eligible for Old Age Assistance an individual must meet the following requirements: :¦ I . Old Age Assistance Age: The applicant must be sixty-five years of age or over. Residence: State. The applicant must have (1) resided in the state for five year's during the last nine immediately preceding application, I and continuously for one year immediately preceding said date, or (2) 25

resided twenty-five consecutive years in the state and one year im - mediately preceding date of application. County Residence: County residence for Old Age Assistance is gained by residing continuously for one year in a county within the state provided the state residence requirements have been met. If the applicant meets the state residence requirements but has not established a county residence, then he is eligible and may apply in the county where he is residing. A recipient may acquire residence in one year's time in a second county while receiving Old Age Assistance from another county. Under the law, each individual gains residence in his own right. Loss of Residence: Residence for Old Age Assistance is lost by continuous residence for one year outside the state. Sixty days prior to the cancellation of his grant, the recipient receives notice that he will become ineligible for further assistance when he has been out of the state a year. Responsible Relatives: He is not eligible if he has responsible rela - tives—children, grandchildren, brothers, sisters, parents—who can sup - port him. Property: If he has deprived himself of property for the purpose of qualifying, he is ineligible. The applicant is ineligible if he is receiving any assistance at public expense except temporary food or fuel, medical and surgical care. Need: He must be in need. Blind Assistance Eligibility requirements for Blind Assistance include: Blindness: For purposes of the program, economic blindness is de - fined as visual acuity of 20/200 or less in the better eye with corrective glasses. An individual with central visual acuity of more than 20/200 in the better eye with proper correction is eligible for Blind Assistance if the widest diameter of the visionary field does not extend beyond an angular distance of 20 degrees. He must not be in need of continuing institutional care. Age: He must be sixteen years of age or older. Residence: State. Applicant must have been a resident of the state of Nebraska for five of the nine years immediately preceding applica - tion, and must have resided continuously in the state for one year im - mediately preceding date of application. County Residence: County residence for Blind Assistance is gained by residing continuously for one year in a county within the state pro - vided the state residence requirements have been met. If the applicant meets the state residence requirements but has not established a county 26

.residence, then, he is eligible and may apply in the county where he is residing. A recipient may acquire residence in one year's time in a second county while receiving Blind Assistance from another county. Under the law, each individual gains residence in his own right. ':;¦. Loss of Residence: Residence for Blind Assistance is lost by con - tinuous residence for one year outside the state. Sixty days prior to the cancellation of his grant, the recipient receives notice that he will be - come ineligible for further assistance when he has been out of the state a year. '. " 1. ¦ . '-'¦ •" .:. : . • . He is not eligible if he is an inmate of a public institution at the time. ¦ -j '•; ¦ ,':.: • ¦•'. .....' Responsible Relatives: He is not eligible if he has responsible rela - tives—children, grandchildren, brothers, sisters, parents—who can sup - port him; »-Sj Property: If he has deprived himself of property for the purpose of qualifying, he'is ineligible. The applicant is ineligible if he is receiving any assistance at public expense, except vocational rehabilitation, medical and surgical care, fuel and food. .-: 1..' : ¦ -. Need: He niust.be in need. Aid to Dependent Children To be eligible for Aid to Dependent Children, a child must be: Age: Under sixteen years of age. Deprived of Parental Support: He must be deprived of parental support or care by reason of death, continued absence from the home, or physical or mental incapacity of a parent. "Continued absence from the home" is defined as a legal divorce, legal separation, or absence from the home due to desertion or separation of at least six months' duration, unless legal proceedings have been in - itiated. Institutional commitment is construed as "continued absence" if it appears that the parent will be absent from the home for at least six months. Children may be deemed to be deprived of parental support by death if the stepfather is unable to provide support. "Physical or mental incapacity" is defined as any physical defect or mental illness which is a major contributing cause of a parent's failure to meet his children's needs for support or care and in which the diag - nosis of the condition indicates that incapacity will continue for at least six months. Disabilities which are subject to remedial treatment do not constitute physical incapacity except in cases of extreme severity. Domicile: The child must be living with father, adoptive father, stepfather, mother, adoptive mother, stepmother, grandfather, grand - mother, brother, brother of the half blood, adoptive brother, stepbrother, 27

sister, sister of the half blood, adoptive sister, stepsister, uncle of the whole or half blood, aunt of the whole or half blood, in the relative's home. Necessary absence from this domicile for the purpose of attend - ance at school, or other temporary absence does not affect the child's eligibility except in the case where the child's needs are supplied from other sources. Residence: State. A child must have resided in the state of Ne - braska for one year immediately preceding the application for Aid to Dependent Children in his behalf. If less than one year old at the time of application, the child must have been born within the state within the year immediately preceding the application, and his mother must have resided within the state for one year immediately preceding the application. There are no legal restrictions regarding removal from the state, but assistance is never continued for more than one year after removal of the child from the state. County Residence: There are no county residence requirements for Aid to Dependent. Children. The county in which the child lives with relatives eligible to receive Aid to Dependent Children grants for him, is deemed the county of the child's residnce. Suitability of Home: The home of the child receiving Aid to De - pendent Children must be suitable; that is, the child must receive good physical care, must have normal opportunities for education, recreation, and desirable family relationships. Need: A child's economic need for Aid to Dependent Children must be based upon a thorough investigation of the financial conditions of the' child's home, and the ability of the responsible relatives to support him. Definition of Need Need for assistance is based upon the budgetary deficiency of an individual applying for assistance. This is determined by a careful and thorough investigation and includes items necessary for the individual's maintenance in decency and health, taking into consideration his require - ments for food, clothing, shelter, fuel, light, water, household equipment and supplies, health, education, and such other items as may be necessary. In establishing need for categorical aid, available resources of a cash value exceeding $300.00 make the individual applying for Old Age Assistance or Blind Assistance ineligible. Should the applicant have a spouse, available resources of a cash value exceeding $600.00 make him ineligible. As a guide in determining need in Aid to Dependent Children cases, available resources in excess of $100.00 per child, or $400.00 for all the children of the family, render the applicant ineligible for Aid to Dependent Children. 28

Liens Since the passage of Legislative Bill 389 on May 22, 1939, Old Age Assistance furnished a recipient constitutes a lien on the real estate owned by him and his spouse. For assistance granted prior to that date, a claim may be made against, the property. Since the beginning of the State Assistance program in 1935, Blind Assistance furnished an individual or his spouse constitutes a,lien on real or personal property except personal effects and household goods owned by the recipient or spouse. A lien is not imposed for assistance furnished to dependent children. Real estate, owned by Indian tribes residing in this state is not subject to the operation of the lien clause. ; : {¦'.'¦'¦¦ ;.¦: ¦¦ ¦ . ..' ¦¦¦ ' Liens on Blind Assistance may be released by the local board when fully paid, when compromised and settled, or when the estate has been probated and the proceeds allowable applied on the lien. Budget A standard budget is employed in determining need of individuals and families who make application for categorical assistance and for certification to the federal programs. By the use of the budget, the worker is able to establish the reasonable expenses of the family as a group, and of individuals of different ages, sex, and activity. Provision is made for food, clothing, shelter, fuel for heating, cooking and light, water, education, community activities, necessary transportation to and from business, schools and clinics, medical services and supplies, inci - dentals such as cleaning materials and personal care items, and there is an allowance for the replacement of kitchen equipment and minor household furnishings. ':.¦¦¦¦.' i ;¦¦.".••¦¦. ¦ . .';¦¦¦' v. : ¦_ In the absence of a home economics consultant on the Department's staff, a committee of staff members and home economists from other agencies is being used in a supervisory capacity. The State Home Eco - nomics Association, at the request of the State Department, selected Dr. Rebekah Gibbons and Miss Florence Atwood to serve on the com - mittee. In April, 1939, Dr. Flora Slocum, Technical Consultant, Bureau of Public Assistance, Social Security Board, spent a week in Nebraska giving invaluable counsel to the committee and the Department. Before the revised budget was adopted, the County Assistance Directors who served as presidents of the five district associations of the state, devoted a day to discussion and recommendation of each item of the budget. Available standard budgets were collected and reviewed; the section of the Manual relating to budgeting -was revised to include a more nearly standardized budget than was previously in use. This revision contains not only cost figures for the items of the budget, but also specified 29

standards of quantity, quality, and price on which costs were based. The budget form with instructions for its use in assembling the expense, income, deficiency, and assistance plan, are embodied in the Manual. Food prices were collected in ten selected representative com - munities. Home Supervisors working under the direction of Miss At - wood, Associate State Director in Charge of Home Economics for the Farm Security Administration, consulted the County Assistance Directors legarding the selection of stores where recipients trade, and secured food prices. It is the plan of the Division to secure food prices each quarter to determine whether revisions in the cost figures should be made from time to time. Clothing lists were reviewed for their adequacy and suitability, and current prices obtained. From all counties of the state, information was gathered concerning costs and other information necessary to provide satisfactorily for such items as fuel, utilities, and shelter. '¦ Although considerable progress has been made in the establishment of a standard budget, further information necessary to determine the quantity, quality and cost standards for most sections of the budget needs to be obtained, as well as continuing to make revisions in accord - ance with price changes. The greatest difficulty with regard to granting assistance is the inadequacy of funds to meet full budgetary deficiency of recipients of Old Age Assistance and Aid to Dependent Children, and of Blind Assist - ance prior to the passage of Legislative Bill S9O in June which provides that Blind Assistance grants shall be paid in full. Before April, 1939, funds were allocated to the counties on the basis of population, and counties were able to pay from fifty to one hundred percent of the budgetary deficiency, depending upon the ratio of eligible persons to the population of the county according to the census of 1930. With the change in the law, effective with the passage of Legislative Bills 420 and 390 in April and in June, all counties pay their Old Age Assistance recipients the same proportion of need, an average of approximately 80 per cent of the budgetary deficiency, and their Aid to Dependent Children recipients an average of approximately 80 per cent of the legal maximum or the budgetary deficiency, which ever is less. In 85 per cent of the Aid to Dependent Children cases, the legal maximum is less than the bud - getary deficiency. The standard budget established by the Department is a very care - fully prepared minimum needs budget. The reduction of grants below this minimum need results in hardship and suffering among the recipients of both Old Age Assistance and Aid to Dependent Children, particularly the latter since their cut is even greater in proportion to need than is the reduction on Old Age Assistance cases. 30

Amount of Grant Old Age Assistance: The maximum monthly grant allowable by Jaw is $30.00 and the minimum is $5.00. If at any time the funds avail - able are insufficient to pay the full amount of Old Age Assistance he is entitled to, then the amount of assistance of each is reduced pro rata in proportion to such deficiency in the total amount available during the period. In cases where this reduction brings the amount of the grant below $5.00, the County Director of Assistance uses his discretion in declaring the case ineligible or awarding a grant of $5.00. , Blind Assistance: The maximum and minimum payments for Blind Assistance recipients are $30.00 and $5.00 respectively. Since the pas - sage of Legislative Bill 390 in the 1939 Session, the Nebraska statutes provide that regardless of the amount of funds available to pay assist - ance grants, the grants to Blind Assistance recipients shall be paid in full. ¦¦; ':)¦'. ¦'.¦¦' .¦.'.-;•¦ ;.¦¦.¦; - : "V ; : V- ¦ Sec. 68-403 C. S. Supp. Nebraska, 1937, provides for temporary assistance for treatment either to prevent blindness or to restore eye - sight. This assistance is provided from state funds without regard as to whether such person is blind according to law. The policy of the Board of Control is to provide such assistance not to exceed $30.00 for any .one treatment or operation to pay the necessary traveling and other expenses to receive such treatment from a hospital or clinic designated by the Board. This assistance may be given also in supplementation to the regular Blind Assistance recipients if the $30.00 maximum grant is not sufficient to provide the needed treatment. Aid to Dependent Children: The maximum grant allowable is $18.00 per month with respect! to one child under the age of sixteen, and $12.00 per month with respect to each of the other dependent children in the home who aye under sixteen years of age. In no event may the amount paid be less than $3.00- per month for each dependent child in the home. If at any time the funds available are insufficient to pay the full amount of Aid to Dependent Children he is entitled to, then the amount of assistance of each is reduced pro rata in proportion to such deficiency in the total amount available during the period. In cases where this re - duction brings the amount of the grant below $3.00 per child, the County ¦Director of Assistance uses his discretion in declaring the case ineligible oil awarding the minimum grant established by law. . ' Reviews The Nebraska State Assistance law provides that reinvestigation shall be made on "each case from time to time and at least once a year, and at anytime the Director of Assistance may direct." In order that the program may be administered efficiently, and that recipients may receive some of the services necessary to their comfort and well-being, 31

the State Department has established the policy that Old Age Assistance and Blind Assistance recipients shall be visited at least every six months, and Aid to Dependent Children cases once every quarter. Fair Hearing The State Assistance laws make provision for an appeal by any taxpayer or any applicant for, or recipient of, Old Age Assistance, Blind Assistance, or Aid to Dependent Children from the decision of the County Assistance Committee to the Board of Control. The appeal may be filed \i the taxpayer or the applicant or recipient believes that the amount recommended by the County Assistance Committee is not just or ade - quate, or that the case has not been given proper consideration. It may be taken in the event of their approval or rejection of an applica - tion, closing of a case, or of an increase or decrease in the amount of the grant. Before an appeal is filed, the County Assistance Director attempts to settle the problem satisfactorily by talking through the situation with the dissatisfied person, by interpreting the limitations of the program and by making a further investigation if it seems advisable. The hearing is conducted in the county in which the recipient resides, by a representative of the Division of Assistance, usually the Field Rep - resentative. The appellant and his witnesses have ample opportunity to give what evidence they wish and to ask questions. All rules of evidence are dispensed with except that testimony is taken under oath. Verbatim transcript of the hearing is sent to the Board of Control, which makes the final decision based on the information contained in the transcript, the appellant's case record, and the recommendation of' the official holding the hearing. The appellant is notified by registered letter of the Board of Control's decision. Safeguarding Confidential Information The policy of the Department provides for safeguarding the con - fidential nature of records, papers filed, and communications, including the names and addresses of applicants for and recipients of assistance. This policy provides that before any confidential information is released to anyone other than an agency of accepted standards, the person or organization requesting such information shall make a formal request of the Board of Control indicating specifically what information is de - sired and the purpose for which it is to be used. Institute Relating to the Blind Miss Evelyn McKay, of the staff of the American Foundation for the Blind, conducted an institute in April for the technical workers of 32

the State staff and students of the graduate school of social work. The material covered in the institute included attitude of the public toward the blind, the general characteristics of the blind people, social adjust - ment of the blind as it applies to every blind person, definition of blind - ness, common causes of blindness, education of the young blind, voca - tional adjustment, administration of assistance to the blind by special facilities to such persons as are handicapped by blindness. ¦...."¦ I - ' : .¦- ' - ¦ ' Evaluation of County Programs t Letters of evaluation of the county assistance programs were sent to the County Assistance Chairmen of forty counties during the fiscal year. The evaluations -were based on data concerning the adequacy of work as reported by all divisions of the Department. From the Division of Assistance information is obtained from the field reviews, Field Rep - resentatives' reports, Certification Section and Case Correspondence section. The following points were embodied in the letters: Thorough - ness in establishing eligibility, adequacy of records, periodic reviews, budgeting, correspondence, reports, general recommendations. : ¦...'¦ . Field Reviews During the year, field reviews were made in thirty-seven counties. In conducting the studies, home visits and investigation of the recipients' resources are made for a percentage of the cases receiving assistance. As of July 1,1939, reviews have been completed in a total of sixty-eight counties. Programs visually covered in the county study are the three categories of asistance, namely Old Age Assistance, Aid to Dependent Children,! and Blind Assistance. In a few instances an investigation of the program of certification to federal agencies is also included. I Field Representatives The field staff of ten persons officially, represent not only the Division of Assistance but the entire Department with the exception of the Child Welfare Division^ They are responsible for the work of the local offices with regard to categorical assistance and certification to federal programs, as well as representing the Divisions of Personnel and of Research and Statistics in the counties. Their function includes both interpreting and explaining to the county staffs and Assistance Com - mittees state policies, procedures and laws, and also informing the State Department through reports, of local programs and conditions affecting them... ¦¦ j" .. v ¦ ;¦: : -:--;- ¦ ;_¦ V. . ¦; ['¦¦¦¦¦.'•¦ -y: ,¦ \:¦"¦¦.. Case!loads as well as average monthly grants for each county and for the state as a whole for each category as of the beginning and end of the fiscal year are given in the statistical report; 33

I f;'. I Inter-Agency Inquiries |: Intev-agency correspondence is handled in the Case Correspondence |; section. The Assistance Division acts as a forwarding center for agencies I that request service or information of another agency which will assist | in developing a plan for its applicant or recipient. A total of 1,401 jc inquiries from 37 states were received and forwarded to the proper agency for action. Table A shows the total number of inquiries by month and by state for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1939. , i Complaints and Inquiries Complaints, either in the form of office interviews or correspondence, are handled by the Case Correspondent. The County Director is given a resume of the problem presented and is often asked for a report. Many interviews, as well as letters, are for the purpose of seeking information about the program, its policies, procedures, or limitations. From Table B, it will be observed that the largest number of letters are in reference to Old Age Assistance. Of this number a large majority are complaints concerning the inadequacy of the grant due to insufficient funds. This table shows a total of 3,260 written inquiries and complaints received, and 807 office interviews, and gives further the number by month and the type of problem involved, for the fiscal year 1938-1939. Works Progress Administration i The Works Progress Administration was initiated by the Relief Appropriation Act of 1935, which appropriated funds to provide relief, I work relief, and to increase employment by providing for useful projects. | The WPA program is designed to employ, at a "security" wage, unem- ' ployed men and women usually found in the labor market, who have been certified as in need and employable by an approved public welfare agency. Local work projects are developed in cooperation with local governmental units. The sponsors assume a portion of the cost of operat - ing the projects. In Nebraska, the Department of Assistance and Child Welfare has been designated the state certifying agency for the Works Progress Ad - ministration. The Division of Assistance, through its local certification representatives, investigates the needs of applicants and certifies those who are in need and employable, according to WPA regulations. To be eligible for WPA employment, the applicant must be eighteen years of age or more, a citizen of the United States, in good health, the economic | head of the family, employable, with training or experience which would qualify him for employment on a WPA project. He must be in need of relief, although not necessarily receiving relief. Need is established | for WPA employment by applying a standard assistance budget used in ' 34

determining need in the other assistance categories. Those receiving public assistance in the form of Old Age Assistance, Blind Assistance, or Aid to Dependent Children are not eligible for WPA employment. Although the certifying agency is not responsible for certifying as to the assigned worker's continuing eligibility for WPA employment nor for his termination of employment, the certification representatives co - operate by notifying the Works Progress Administration when they receive information which apparently indicates that the worker is no longer eligible. They also investigate complaints regarding eligibility of workers and when requested by the WPAj Division of Employment, make investigations on certain cases. j During December, 1938, and January and February, 1939, the local certification representatives assumed responsibility for certifying needy families for a special allotment of WPA clothing. A total of 58,429 garments were made available to needy.people in this state. During the year July 1, 1938, through June 30, 1939, there was a total of 18,345 applications for WPA employment. Of this number, local certification representatives certified 13,328 cases and rejected 5,017 applications, inaintaining an average monthly certified load of 35,169. Of this number, the Works Progress Administration employed an average of 27,545 per - sons per month. (See Table C.) ; National Youth Administration The National Youth Administration has designated the Department of Assistance and Child Welfare as its state certifying agency. The Division of Assistance, through its local certification representatives, is i-esponsible for certification of eligible youth for employment on NYA work projects. (The Department has no responsibility in connection with pie NYA Student Aid Program.) Young men and women from needy families, who are between the ages of eighteen and twenty-four, un - married, not in regular attendance at school, in good health, unemployed arid in need of employment, are eligible. Need is established according to the regular procedure used in determining need for other categories of aid. ¦ / '¦:¦ ¦ :.-', '. ¦ ¦ ¦¦.;¦:•.'. ¦ - The purpose of the NYA work program is to provide work experi - ence and training, under good supervision, and to help meet the needs of the youth by making it possible for him to earn an amount equal to one-third of jthe.WPA wage for that community. The National Youth Administration is careful to maintain only those work projects which will provide useful training. This work does not interfere with the 'youth's opportunity to seek private employment, since he is employed 6nly about one-third of the time usually required in full-time employ - ment. Because of the NYA work experience, many young people have been able to secure full-time private employment. 35

During the fiscal year, July 1, 1938, through June 30, 1939, 4,185 certifications were issued, and 846 applications were rejected. Of this number, the National Youth Administration employed a monthly average of 2,506 youth. (See Table C.) Farm Security Administration The Department of Assistance and Child Welfare operates as a referral agency in connection with the Farm Security Administration subsistence grant program. The local certification representatives of the Division of Assistance investigate the needs of applicants for Farm Security grants and certify those eligible to the local Farm Security Administration Supervisor. The Farm Security Administration provides emergency subsistence grants for farmers and farm laborers living in the open country, who, because of insufficient resources, are unable to meet their own subsist - ence needs. These grants are available only for food, shelter, clothing, and medical care, and are given for a one, two, or three month period. Since cases are frequently dropped from the rolls at the end of this period, the grant ease load fluctuates considerably, thus making it neces - sary to service the applications of many farm families several times during the year. Local certification representatives received 17,992 applications during the fiscal year July 1, 1938, through June 30, 1939, and of this number, 14,325 were certified as needy and referred to the Farm Security Ad - ministration. (See Table C.) Civilian Conservation Corps The Civilian Conservation Corps plays an important role in the public welfare program in Nebraska. The purpose of the Corps is three - fold: First, to provide work and training for unemployed young men and veterans; second, to assist needy families through allotment of a proportion of the enrollees' wages; and third, to rehabilitate, conserve, and improve the nation's natural resources. There are four federal departments cooperating in this program, namely, the Department of Agriculture, the Department of the Interior, the Department of Labor, and the War Department. The cost of operat - ing the Civilian Conservation Corps program is borne entirely by these four federal departments. The Department of Assistance and Child Wel - fare in Nebraska and the local county assistance offices bear only the expense of selecting enrollees for the companies and providing trans - portation to the recruiting stations. The Department of Assistance and Child Welfare was designated the state selecting agency by the Department of Labor. The State Assistance Director is the State Selecting Agent, and the Assistant Super- 36

visor of the Division of Assistance is the Supervisor of CCC Selection. The local certification representatives are the.local selecting agents. They investigate applicants and select for CCC enrollment young men, seventeen to twenty-three years old, unmarried, not in regular attendance ' at school, unemployed and in need of employment. Boys from families receiving relief are given preference in selection over those from non - relief families. The youth selected must be in good physical condition, of good character, and must make a monthly allotment of $22 to needy dependents'. Youth without dependents must deposit with the Finance Officer' $22; of the monthly wages, which is returned to him upon dis - charge from the Corps. The junior enrollee receives not less than $30 per month lin wages, plus maintenance, medical care, and clothing. He may also participate in the camp educational progz-am, which offers courses in academic subjects and vocational training. The enrollment period is for six months. An enrollee may be honor - ably discharged before the expiration of the term only to accept other employment which will better his condition, to attend school, or to re - turn home jbecause of conditions which demand his services there. Young men who have satisfactorily completed six months' service in the Corps may re-enroll for another term. Junior enrollees are limited to twenty - four months'service, v ¦;¦:¦¦"..:;. ¦; The local selecting agent is responsible not only for the selection of boys for enrollment, but for servicing those cases during their stay in camp. For example, changes of allotment, and the granting of honor - able discharges and leave to attend school are based largely upon the investigation and recommendation of the local selecting agents. Personnel histories of CCC enrollees are furnished by the CCC camp officials to the local selecting agents so that upon discharge the youth may be helped intelligently to secure satisfactory employment. . i In February, 1939, there was a change of policy in regard to age •of selectees. Up to this time, approximately one T third of the boys selected were seventeen years old. The policy now in effect gives pref - erence in selection to applicants eighteen to twenty-three years of age. Young| men may apply at any time at the local assistance offices, but selectees are sent to .the recruiting stations for enrollment only four times each year, in January, April, July, and October. During these enrollment periods the Department of Labor makes a requisition of a certain number of junior- enrollees to fill the vacancies in the Nebraska companies. The number is determined from reports furnished by the Army and jby the Division of Assistance, which indicate the number of vacancies and ithe estimated number of prospective enrollees available. Itjfa the responsibility of the State Selecting Agency to'establish county quotas, based upon need, population, and the number of boys available jii the county. (The Division of Assistance has ho responsibility in con - nection with the enrollment of veterans in the Civilian Conservation 'Corps.) : I-.-¦¦. ¦¦;.' ' '„'¦:¦ ' -•¦¦ ¦ ...¦_."¦¦ v¦; 37

During the fiscal year, July 1, 1938, through June 30, 1939, local selecting agents investigated 4,564 applications. Of this number, 2,739 were enrolled in the Corps. Of those enrolled, 1,339 were from families receiving some form of assistance, and 845 were from families eligible for relief, but not actually receiving relief. The average number of Nebraska enrollees in camp the year round is approximately 3,000. There are thirteen camps located in Nebraska and two Nebraska com - panies in South Dakota. (See Table C.) Surplus Commodities The Division of Assistance is responsible for the determination of eligibility of applicants for Federal Surplus Commodities. The first of each month, the local certification representatives, as agents for the Division, certify to the local commodity clerks a list of eligible recipients. According to the policy in effect in Nebraska, Surplus Commodities are available to all persons receiving county general relief, county Soldiers' and Sailors' relief, and Farm Security Administration subsistence grants. Recipients of Old Age Assistance, Blind Assistance, and Aid to De - pendent Children, and persons certified for WPA are eligible if investi - gation discloses a budgetary deficiency. The local certification representative certifies eligible sponsors of School Lunch programs for commodities, and the Supervisor of the Division of Assistance certifies the eligibility of public institutions caring for indigent persons. During the fiscal year, July 1, 1938, through June 30, 1939, the total average monthly case load eligible for Surplus Commodities was 33,754. Of this number, there were 5,564 general relief cases, 8,422 Old Age Assistance cases, 3,308 Aid to Dependent Children cases, 49 Blind Assist - ance cases, 10,215 WPA eases, 5,589 Farm Security Administration cases, 607 cases for whom special authorization was given by the Supervisor of the Division on an individual needs basis. Commodities were made available to a monthly average of 39 School Lunch programs serving 2,375 pupils, and 8 public institutions caring for 2,673 indigent persons. (See section on Surplus Commodities Division, and refer to Table D.) 38

Pak 111 SURPLUS COMMODITY DISTRIBUTION The operations of the Federal Surplus Commodities Corporation have two purposes: to help people on relief rolls, and to keep farmers from being overwhelmed by surpluses of the commodities which they produce. The Corporation seeks to accomplish this two-fold objective by buying up acute surpluses of farm products, and supplying them to State Agencies for relief distribution. The purchase of these commodities, and their distribution to persons on relief rolls, is conducted in order; to encourage domestic consumption through the removal of surplus agricultural products from the normal channels of trade and commerce. Distribution of these items as surplus commodities is next made to persons who have been certified as eligible to receive them. It is optional with the County Board in each county in Nebraska, whether or not the county will take advantage of these commodities. If the county chooses to participate,' agreements are made with the State Agency as to rules and regulations regarding storage and handling of the various items offered. Surplus commodities are shipped, freight paid, to the state in which they are to be distributed, but after receipt at designated receiving stations, any additional distribution costs must be paid by the state and participating counties. The following tables give a j report of the extent of the Surplus Commodity program in Nebraska during the fiscal year July 1, 193S to June<3o, 1939. ; 1 j 155

The lowering of cost per case served from 94c 1 in 1937-38 to 76(f in 1938-39 is the result of (1) simplification in reporting forms, (2) the elimination of all but the minimum required mechanics of opera - tion, and (3) the advantage of an increased number of carload receipts of surplus food items which permitted a more favorable placement of cars and consequent shorter hauls to county ware - houses. Distribution of foodstuffs during the year in Nebraska more than doubled the output of any previous year, and totaled 25,278,346 pounds. Six hundred seventy-seven more carloads of merchandise were purchased by the FSCC in Nebraska than were shipped into the State. Nebraska^ therefore, benefited considerably from large receipts of surplus food for relief clients, while manufacturers and producers within the State par - ticipated so extensively in the purchasing program of the FSCC that the sales made by them to the Corporation far exceeded shipments into Nebraska from other States. 162

Inventories at the end [of the biennium appear to be in excellent shape. A gradual decline in the number of complaints has been notice - able, and all such cases brought to the attention of the Division had been disposed of at the end of the period, so far as known. This would indicate a high type of work on the part of the various county staffs. Inter - department and other agency relations with the Commodity Division appear to be on a satisfactory basis at this time. Information from the FSCC Washington office indicates that a liberal supply of. surplus foods will be available in the future, and in that event commodity distribution should continue to be of considerable value to the Welfare Program in Nebraska, supplementing the food and clothing supplies of many clients at d reasonable cost of distribution to the State, Counties, and W.P.A.: 163
